dialogues.speaker: FIRST IMAGE
dialogues.text: Whites, Blacks, Browns, Indians, Women, Gays, Tree Lovers, Christians, Abortion Activists, Nazis, Atheists, Hunters, Animal Lovers, Farmers, heckling, chanting, Screaming, fighting. The CAMERA, low, like a child, ZIGZAGS THROUGH this sea of rage TO an unyielding line of Police, and BURSTS THROUGH their outstretched clubs, TO REVEAL, like some mirage above, the Supreme Court, FRAMED AGAINST the sky.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Any of those signs got my name on ‘em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUSTICE ROSENBERG, an ancient man, sits in a wheelchair,. watching through a window. GRAY GRANTHAM, a mid- thirtyish journalist, stands beside hin.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Quite a few.

dialogues.speaker: ROSENBERG
dialogues.text: What do they say?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: The usual. Death to Rosenberg. Retire Rosenberg. Cut off the oxygen.

dialogues.speaker: ROSENBERG
dialogues.text: (chuckling) . That's my favorite. (squinting at Grantham) Of course, you did pretty good by me your last time out: ‘Rosenberg equals government over business, the individual over government, the environment over everything. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosenberg’

dialogues.speaker: ROSENBERG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And the Indians, give 'em whatever they want.'

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: That wasn't my line, sir. It was a quote.

dialogues.speaker: ROSENBERG
dialogues.text: From one of your unnamed Senior White House Officials. Senior White House son of a bitch you should have said! Got in there by whipping up these people, one against the other. Never fails to amaze me what a man will do to get an oval office.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: There's a report, sir, that your doctor is urging you to resign. 8 rheumy, old eyes look straight up at Grantham's.

dialogues.speaker: ROSENBERG
dialogues.text: Son, the present senior White House official is not appointing my successor, if I have to have my mummy sittin’ on the bench. I’m going to sit here in this wheelchair and gasp my oxygen and Protect the Indians, the blacks, the women, the poor, the handicapped and the environment -- (chuckling) “Oh, yes, and let's not forget The Constitution. And only the Senior Official in the Sky can do one damned thing about it.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We saw today, on the steps of what should be our most cherished building, --

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: CALLAHAN is about forty-five but could pass for ten years younger. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: On what should be our most cherished day, the day the Supreme Court of our land goes into session, what is happening te our Founding Fathers’ dream. Abortion clinics bombed, doctors attacked and beaten, gays attacked by people who dare call themselves Christians, churches attacked by militant gays, white Supremacists attacking Blacks, Hispanics, Asians. America's favorite pastime now is hate.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY SHAW
dialogues.text: An attractive young girl. She looks at her professor with pride and admiration.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This is the country ble d with the greatest gift of governance bestowed on any peoples: The Constitution. It's an appropriate day to be exploring a dissenting opinion of Justice Rosenberg, the last of the great judicial activists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of the SEA washes over her. And then a muffled ENGINE HUM. The HUM grows LOUDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small craft floats in the direction of the pier, a camouflaged silhouette crouching low, working the motor The HUM stops. The craft stalls thirty feet from the pier.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: A man dressed like an old farmer, with Straw hat, bib. etc., looking towards the ENGINE sound. He places a cigarette between his lips.

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN THE BOAT, (V.Q.)
dialogues.text: What kind of cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Lucky Strike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man climbs in on the driver's side. The other door opens and a black Adidas gym bag is thrown onto the seat. The man from the boat climbs in beside it. He has a heavy beard, dark glasses, and wears a black turtleneck He takes off his glasses and rubs his eyes. They have an intensity we won't forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck stops at the corner of Thirty-First and M Streets in Georgetown. The man from the boat grabs his gym bag and hits the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: The man from the boat enters.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM DOOR
dialogues.text: A dark-complected hand knocks on the door.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE FROM INSIDE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man from the boat stands at the door.

dialogues.speaker: MAN FROM BOAT
dialogues.text: (in perfect English) Looking for Mr. Sneller. —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A distinguished middle-aged MAN stands at the door. Mr. Sneller?

dialogues.speaker: MAN FROM BOAT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Yes. Edwin F, Sneller.

dialogues.speaker: MAN FROM BOAT
dialogues.text: The sound of PAPER being SLID across carpet. The man looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of envelope eased from under the door.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS UP TO the Man as he picks up the envelope and opens it. There is a memorandum and a key inside. He walks to the room next door. A copy of i Rost lies in front of the door. He puts the key in the door, picks up the paper and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PHONE RINGS. He picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: SNELLER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Everything's in place.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: 411 the money must be there when I arrive in Zurich. :

dialogues.speaker: SNELLER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It will be there, if the job is finished.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: It will be finished. He hangs up and stretches out on the bed with the paper.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON POST
dialogues.text: A formal photograph of the Supreme Court Justices above a story about the first day of its new session. The story is by Gray Granthan. : The caption below the Photograph identifies the youngish man next to Rosenberg as Justice Jensen. The subheading of the story is: JENSEN THE WILDCARD.

dialogues.speaker: MAN FROM BOAT
dialogues.text: Reading. A mischievous smile crosses his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Glce Ceorgetown House. A plainclothes man sits outside the house. CAMERA MOVES PAST him TO a lighted window on the ground floor, and then MOVES THROUGH the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Justice Rosenberg is asleep in a special hospital bed. A male nurse lowers the lights and draws the drapes. He sits down in a chair, reaches for a mouse, and turns ON the TELEVISION. He flicks the channels until he comes to "STUDS": Women and men telling semi-prurient tales about their dating. CAMERA MOVES INTO the face of the male nurse, intent. on the program; a closet door in back of him inches open. The nurse's face breaks into a delighted smile at some lewd comment. The tip of a gun APPEARS ON the SIDE OF the SCREEN next to his head. The smile freezes; his face falls OUT OF FRAME. A dull thud as the head hits the floor. CAMERA PANS OVER TO the old justice on the bed. Blood trickles from his mouth, his eyes closed now in eternal sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Door opens Stealthily. A man in running shorts and Reeboks,’ clean-shaven, short blond hair under a cap, slides out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man runs TOWARDS CAMERA. He stops for a moment to look back. He turns back TO CAMERA, his eyes fill the Screen, the eyes of the man from the boat. An instant, and he’s gone. CAMERA HOLDS ON the alley. No sound except from the TV set of a neighboring house:

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The latest polls do not look good for the President. With the first primaries just months away, his approval rating continues on its downward spiral.  7.

dialogues.speaker: TICKET
dialogues.text: AS a male hand scoops it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All men. The ecstatic all-male GROANS and GRUNTS that emanate from the sceen indicate the kind of film that holds their interest, A man in a fedora and sunglasses walks down the aisle and sits in @ corner, away from the others. He takes off the hat and sunglasses revealing a face we saw in the picture in the Post: Justice Jensen, the wild card of the Court. A bag of popcorn falls INTO VIEW ABOVE his head, as some- one sits down in the seat above. CAMERA PANS. UP TO the bag of popcern sitting on a tight- jeaned lap. A strand of yellow nylon ski rope is wrapped like a belt from around the waist. A familiar dark-complected hand reaches into the bag of popcorn. CAMERA FOLLOWS the popcorn-filled hand TO the new man’s face. He sports an earring, horn-rimmed shades, and a mustache. CAMERA MOVES INTO CLOSE SHOT of his eyes, the eyes of the man from the boat. : CAMERA MOVES DOWN WITH the man's hand as it reaches down to the popcorn bag again. This time the hand goes under the popcorn bag and pulls the strand of yellow nylon ski rope from his waist. CAMERA PANS DOWN TO Jensen's face below, fixated on the Screen and the magnified sounds of lust. The nylon rope loops just under his larynx with a violent wrench. The rope yanks downward, snapping the head over the back of the seat. The neck breaks cleanly. CAMERA PANS UP TO the seat above. It is empty.

dialogues.speaker: LAMINATED WHITE HOUSE PASS
dialogues.text: An I.D. photograph of an old black man; next to his name, JOHN SARGENT. The I.D. specifies he is a White House Janitor. CAMERA PANS UP TO Time Clock at 4:45 A.M.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER IN THE BOOTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How. ya doin', Sarge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The OFFICER IN THE LOOT!: hands the I.D. back to the old black man. SARGE (JOHN SARGENT;

dialogues.speaker: OLD BLACK MAN
dialogues.text: No complaints. CAMERA PANS WITH Sarge as he trudges up the driveway. CAMERA PANS SLIGHTLY LEFT to reveal the White House. The lights in the Oval Office Pop on.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: They found Rosenberg around 1:00 A.M.

dialogues.speaker: OVAL OFFICE
dialogues.text: The President sits behind his desk. COAL, his Chief of Staff, faces him.

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: His nurse was also murdered. Jensen was found in some queer club two hours later. Voyles called me, wildly uspet. This is hardly good for the reputation of the F.B.I. He and Gminski are on the way.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: Gminski?

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: "| The C.I.A. should be included, at least for now. I[ Suggest you address the nation in a couple of hours. We have to wait ‘til daylight, at least seven, if we want an audience. A coat and tie at 7 A.M. may seem-a bit rehearsed. How about a cardigan?

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: You want me to address the nation in this hour of crisis in a sweater?

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: It's Rally Round the Leader time. Your approval ratings will go through the roof. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Directors CcOAl (CONT'D) I've called Justice and instructed them to begin a preliminary list of nominees. The restructuring of the court will be your legacy. VOYLES and GMINSKI enter.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: Any suspects?

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: Too early. We'll have ballistics and autopsies by late this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: I would like a report on your security and where it broke down.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: You're assuming it broke down, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: We have two dead judges, both of whom were being protected by the F.B.I. (turning to Gminski) Bob, I wans a straight answer. Are these killings in any way linked to any agency, operation, "| group, whatever, of the United States Government?

dialogues.speaker: GMINSKI
dialogues.text: I'm shocked you would even think it.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: Rosenberg did not believe in mational security. He made thousands of enemies in intelligence. Just check it out, okay.

dialogues.speaker: GMINSKI
dialogues.text: Okay. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: IT suggest we meet here at five this afternoon, gentlemen. Is that agreeable? Gminski and Voyles nod.

dialogues.speaker: CLOSED EYES OF DARBY SHAW
dialogues.text: As the first rays of morning sunlight fall over them.

dialogues.speaker: EARLY MORNING
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK TO a FULL SHOT of her, snuggled against the sleeping figure of Callahan. From French doors opening onto a balcony of a TV set across the courtyard:

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, the President of the United States. Darby opens her eyes, reaches over to the bedside table for the mouse and TURNS ON the TELEVISION.

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION SET ACROSS FROM BED
dialogues.text: The President sits behind the desk in a brown cardigan with no tie.

dialogues.speaker: . DARBY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Thomas! Wake up!

dialogues.speaker: DARBY AND CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: Callahan sits up, rubbing his eyes. He has all the symptoms of a man with a hangover.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Last night, a night that like Pearl Harbor, shall live in infamy, Supreme Court Justices Rosenberg and Jensen were assassinated.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: Cheartbroken) Rosenberg? Murdered?  11.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I can assure each and every American that everything is being and will be done to bring the culprit or culprits to justice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Callahan and Darby, now dressed, are having coffee.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: Half a lifetime later and we're back in Dallas.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Obviously, someone or some group wants a different court. The election is next year. A president at least halfway closer to the center may be elected President. Why take a chance on his nominations? Kill them now, a year before the election.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: But why Jensen? He was nominated by this administration. In most issues, he is one hundred and eighty degrees from Rosenberg. . (rising) I need a bloody mary.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Don't you think you had enough *, last night?

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: I can not bear to look at this world sober. CAMERA MOVES IN CLOSER TO Darby's, face, frustrated and concerned. LOUDSPEAKER (¥.0.) All passengers on Air France Concord Flight to Paris please board at Gate 1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sedate, well-dressed passengers in first-class lounge as they rise and exit TOWARDS CAMERA. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A conserv-tively-dressed businessman walks TOWARDS u~, clean-shaven, his hair a nondescript brownish color. He stops, waiting for the couple in frent of him to collect their bags. The CAMERA MOVES INTO his eyes, the eyes of The Man In The Boat.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Whoever did the actual killings was fed a lot of information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President is having his 5:00 P.M. with Gminski, Coal, and a miserable-locking Voyles.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: Such as?

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: Such as that Jensen had become expert at avoiding F.B.I. protection, and that Rosenberg had refused a security system in his house, and kept our boys outside.

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: You're Suggesting a conspiracy.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: Then who are the conspirators? Who are your suspects?

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: | This must be kept very quiet.

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: Of course it's confidential. You're in the Oval Office. Voyles gives Coal a look that Says, "And you know that's the problem.”

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: We know of at least eleven members of the Underground Army who've been in the D.C. area for a week. We suspect them in at least a hundred bombings of abortion clinies, A.C.L.U. offices, porno houses, gay clubs, all over the country. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And there’s an Aryan group called White Resistance we've been watching. The leader was spotted Monday in the demonstration outside the Court.

dialogues.speaker: GMINSKI
dialogues.text: The truth is you don't have a Prime suspect at the moment, just a few good possibilities.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: You mean we may never know who did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors to The Oval Office open. Voyles and Gminski enter into the hallway. They pass Sarge, the old black man, cleaning.

dialogues.speaker: COMPUTER PRINTOUT
dialogues.text: of the Supreme Court's docket.

dialogues.speaker: CLUTTERED STUDY CARREL
dialogues.text: on the fifth level of the Tulane Law Library. Darby Shaw stands between racks of Seldom-used law bocks Scanning the printout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby pecks away at the keyboard, finds what she wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby stands at @ PRINTER as it SPEWS forth page after page.

dialogues.speaker: PAGES
dialogues.text: the printer is spewing forth. Page after page of appe. pending in the eleven federal appellate courts around the country.  14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Da.oy places a six-inch thich Summary of the eleven docke on her desk. She kicks off her shoes and she begins to plow through th printouts.

dialogues.speaker: EVANGELIST, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The Justice Rosenbergs are today's Anti-Christs, committed to the rights of criminals, atheists, agnostics, and the perverted, those the devil has possessed. 4 TV late night show FILLS the SCREEN. A thousand chanting people on their knees, led by a shouting evangelical leader.

dialogues.speaker: EVANGELIST, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We must protect our country and ourselves from them. A group of reporters sitting around a table in a show like Washington Week in Review. Gray Grantham is among then.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHOR, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Today that evangelist issued a Statement saying Rosenberg's death was God's will. And there were a lot of people who felt that way.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM GRANTHAM, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Justice Rosenberg told me only hours before he died, that the ‘, last presidential campaign was so divisive... INT. CALLAHAN’S APARTMENT - NIGHT Callahan is sitting in front of the TV with a drink. The door opens and Darby enters.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: So exploitative of fear and Prejudice, that it would inevitably lead to violence. Darby kisses the back of his head. He reaches up with his hand and squeezes hers, (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: That Grantham is a man after my own heart.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHOR, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We'll return, after a message.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: (muting the TV sound) Where've you been? It's almost midnight.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: The library. I studied a printout of the Supreme Court docket. Tr even made a list of possible Suspects, and threw it in the garbage because they'd be obvious to anyone. And then I looked for areas that Jensen and Rosenberg might have in common. Jensen -- with some notable exceptions -- was generally consistent in his protection of the rights of criminal defendants, he has written three majority opinions strongly protective of the environment, and he was near perfect in support of tax Protestors. Have you eaten?

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: In @ liquid sort of way. How about a drink?

dialogues.speaker: / DARB'
dialogues.text: Why don't I make us both some tea?

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: That's my girl. Always trying to set a good example. (rising) I'll stick with bourbon.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Everyone's assuming the motive is hatred or revenge, or an attempt to influence the social agenda of the Court. But what if the issues involve old-fashioned material greed? A case that involves a great deal of money. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: C.
dialogues.text: (pouring his bourbon) Do you realize that every little legal scholar in the country is doing exactly what you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: If there are enough of us, maybe one of us is going to get lucky.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: As for me, I'm canceling classes for a week. The gifts of reason are puny weapons in the face of such brutality.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: That's not what you taught me. Callahan turns ON the SOUND again.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHOR, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Let's explore what kind of justices the President will select to replace them. For background, we have a piece on his campaign oratory of three years ago.

dialogues.speaker: TV SCREEN
dialogues.text: Image of the President accepting the nomination at his party's convention.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ‘ It is time the majority of right- thinking citizens took back this country from the special social interest groups who want special social rights. Great applause from the convention. Coal sits in back of the President, cuing the applause.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: You don't think you're really going to solve this crime.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I can’t stay away from it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: o~ CONTINUED: the case and give me back my faith

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: } So you will work long hours, solve ‘ in reason.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I'm not that dumb.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: No. Just that caring.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Darby enters and stops at a counter.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Can I help. you? Darby slides a Strip of paper through the window. DARBY . pam I would like to see this file.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: It's public record, isn't it? Semi-public.

dialogues.speaker: . . DARBY
dialogues.text: Are you familiar with the Freedom of Information Act?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There sre no tables or chairs, only file cabinets and boxes lining the walls.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: (pointing) This first file cabinet has all the pleadings and correspondence. The rest is discovery, exhibits, i and the trial.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: When was the trial? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Last summer. It went on for two months.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Where's the appeal?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Not perfected yet. I think the deadline is November first. Darby opens a drawer full of Pleadings.

dialogues.speaker: DRAWER
dialogues.text: as Darby goes through it. She stops at a particular file and removes it from the drawer,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby sits at a personal computer going over her notes. There are great piles of then. KNOCK on door OVER:

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Callahan is at the deor, holding a bag containing a pizza and a bottle of wine.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: You have not returned my calls.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I thought we had a rule, Thomas. About coming to ay place.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: What we do is not illegal. (smiling) On second thought, in this state everything's illegal.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I don't think the Dean would be enthusiastic.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: The Dean is not my type.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Professor Callahan, you are impossible.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: Rear Professor Callahan.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Dear Professor Callahan, you are im... There is a KNOCK on the door.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE STARK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Darby? It's Alice. Are you there? I'm going out for a burger. Feel like joining me? Callahan puts his hand over Darby's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALICE, a plain girl who sat next to Darby in class, waits at the door.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE STARK
dialogues.text: Darby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She KNOCKS again, 2 beat, and then the sound of FOOTSTEPS going down the stairs. Callahan removes his hand from Darby’s mouth.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: Almost caught in flagrante delicto by the dreaded Alice. He takes out the pizza box and the liter of wine and puts them down on the kitchenette counter. She opens a drawer and removes s corkscrew.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: I blew my cover because I'm hungry for intellectual discussion and animal sex, the sort of thing I find unsatisfactory with your answering machine. And I'm leaving town tomorrow. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ~ “DARBY The Con Law Conference in ) Washington.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: Right. He goes over to her desk and looks over the books and Keroxes and notes.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: So, Ms. Shaw, who done it? (looking over her notes) You've got some obscure suspect -unknown to the F.B.I., the C.I.A., the Secret Service and one thousand police departments?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I bad one, which I have now discarded.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: You skipped classes for three days, ignored me, and now you're throwing it away? i DARBY (pointing to the notes on the table) Look at it. But don't laugh, okay? You were right. It was ludicrous of me to think thet I could solve it. What you call ‘| the hubris of the young.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: Don't knock the hubris that I love. She brings over a glass of wine and hands it to him. He takes it, but she sees that his hand is shaking.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: Sorry. It's been a rough week for the likes of me.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: iim sorry. I kind of deserted you oo this week. Not the greatest timing. He takes her in his arms and kisses her. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CALLA i God, I've missed you! She snuggles in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: I hate it, you know. Missing any one that much. It’s not supposed to be my thing. They start to make love. CAMERA starts to SINK WITH them DOWN ONTO the couch, but STOPS AT the table desk as they go out of sight. CAMERA HOLDS ON the sheaf of papers comprising Darby's notes.

dialogues.speaker: ' GRANTHAM GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: sitting in a booth.

dialogues.speaker: G
dialogues.text: How's the President?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM AND SARGE
dialogues.text: The old black janitor, who is sitting opposite him.

dialogues.speaker: SARGE
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: . GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Not Coal. The elected one.

dialogues.speaker: SARGE
dialogues.text: Swell. Just swell. (heavy irony) He's awful tore up about Rosenberg, of course.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: I bet.

dialogues.speaker: SARGE
dialogues.text: And all het up about restructuring the court. Thinks it'll make his place in history.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: That sounds like Coal. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SARGE
dialogues.text: There's a short list of nominees. The original had twenty or so names, then it was cut to eight. (handing him a sheet of paper under the table) I got two.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: What about the investigation?

dialogues.speaker: SARGE
dialogues.text: I haven't heard much, but as usual I'll keep my ears open.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON POST
dialogues.text: held in a man's hand. Article headlined: White House Court Short List by Gray Grantham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Callahan is reading the article as he finishes a drink. He motions for another. . :

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You're reading that damned Grantham piece. Callahan looks in back of him. He smiles as he recognizes his old friend, GAVIN VERHEEK. He gets up and they shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: One of these years I want to see your name on that list. Of our whole damned class, you're the one we bet would make the Court.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: These days it’s hard enough to make my class. (waving for another drink) Who leaked that information, Gavin? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: Coal blasted the director this morning, said it had to be one of us at the F.B.I. But the director thinks it was leaked by Coal, himself, to test the waters.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: That bastard ran the most divisive campaign in twenty years, and the President acted as if it wasn't happening.

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: The President doesn’t know the half of what he does, and Coal telis him that's essential, to protect his deniability.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: Deniability: It's an Eighties word that came in with Eighties morals.

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: Which brings me to, how old's the latest? Twenty-four, but very mature. He downs his drink.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: Her father was killed in a plane crash four yesrs ago. Fortunately, ‘, her mother got a nice settlement.

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: Then she has money.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: She's comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: Do you have a photo?

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: No. She's not a grandchild or a poodle. Who killed them, Gavin?

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: Thomas, I'm just a lawyer with the bureau, not an agent.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: AS I recall, you have great ears, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: The truth? We don't have a clue. Callahan reaches into his coat pocket and removes a thick envelope.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: Take a look at this when you get a chance.

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: It's sort of a brief. Darby wrote it, my girl. She's a brilliant student, with a passion for constitutional law.

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: Sounds like a fellow I knew at law school.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: She took off four days last week and came up with her own theory, which she has now discarded. But read it anyway. It's fascinating. I mean, it can’t hurt, can it?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: . (low and timid) Is this Gary Srentham with the Washington Poat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray is in bed, barely awake, holding the phone.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to call you at such a crazy hour. But I'm on my way to work and stopped at a pay phone. I can't call from home or the affice. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: What kind of office?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'm an attorney.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Private or government?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'd rather not say. (blurting it out) I may know something about Rosenberg and Jensen. Are you recording this?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Can this call be traced? Z'm not recording and I won't trace it.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I think I may know who Killed them.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Why don't you tell me your name, okay? I swear it's confidential.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Garcia.

dialogues.speaker: G
dialogues.text: That's not a real name, is it?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: No. I think I stumbled across Something at the office that I was not supposed to see. .

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Do you have a copy of it?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I need to think about this. I haven't slept in a week, and I'a not thinking rationally. He hangs up. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Grantham looks at the row of numbers on his phone and punches seven digits, waits, then six more, then four more. He scribbles a number on 4 pad by the phone and hangs up. He pulls out the Yellow Pages from a shelf, flips through them and stops at Pay Phones Inc.

dialogues.speaker: YELLOW PAGES
dialogues.text: We FOLLOW Grantham's finger UNTIL it hits the number he has just scribbled on the pad. It lists the number at Fifteenth Street in Pentagon City.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S HAND
dialogues.text: gives the envelope containing Darby's brief to a woman's hand.

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: (to secretary) Send this to Eric East. Teli him to look it over when he has a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coal enters to find K.0. LEWIS and ERIC EAST waiting. The President is not there.

dialogues.speaker: K.0. LEWIS
dialogues.text: The director had some pressing business. He sends his apologies.

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: (amused) And his underlings. With the President away, he doesn't care to meet with me alone. K.0. Lewis places a four-inch stack of the latest reports on the table. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric East 27.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC EAST
dialogues.text: The French authorities were routinely reviewing footage taken by the security cameras at che Paris airport, and they thought they recognized a face that might be Khamel's, the terrorist. He may have been on a flight that arrived from Dulles about ten hours after we found Jensen's body.

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: Okay. Wht if it's Khamel, and what if he was involved in the killings?

dialogues.speaker: K.0. LEWIS
dialogues.text: It means we'll never find him. There are at least nine countries, including Israel, actively stalking him right now.

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Maybe a small new wrinkle. pulls out a copy of Darby's brief from his dispatch case.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC EAST
dialogues.text: It's a theory that's surfaced in the last twenty-four hours, and Director Voyles is quite intrigued by it. He's afraid it could be ‘ damaging to the President.

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: (stone- faced) How's that?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC EAST
dialogues.text: (placing the brief on the table) It's.all here in this report. Coal looks down at it, stone-faced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby's brief.  28.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC EAST
dialogues.text: Well, he didn't exactly sweat i . But when he gets that great Stone-face you know he's not exactly happy.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: We all know it's a long shot, unworthy of serious attention, but how often does something come along that makes Coal sweat and run for cover!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President emerges from Air Force One. The usual press coverage. Coal stands, a gray eminence in the rear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President sinks low in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: Oksy. What's so important? Coal hands over a copy of Darby's brief.

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: An eager-beaver law student at Tulane wrote this. The premise is so farfetched it's absurd, but Voyles, for whatever reasons of his own, has decided he must ‘| pursue.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: We can't control his investigation.

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: I think you should ask Gminski to have the C.I.A. investigate. If we know more than Voyles, you can convince him to back off.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: It's domestic. The C.I.A. has no business snooping around. It's illegal.

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: Technically.

dialogues.speaker: PRESTNENT ,
dialogues.text: What about Barr and the unit? Isn't that what you call them?

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: L've talked to Barr. They're good for small, specific missions, 1ike research, wiretapping, even petty burglary; but they hardly have the resources of the C.I.A. The President takes the brief and tosses it on the empty seat next to him.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: The person mentioned in the brief. Is it someone we both know?

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A non descript MAN #1 sits on a park bench with a brown paper bag. He takes out a banana and peels it. An equally non descript MAN #2 sits down next to him with a bag of peanuts.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (shelling the peanuts) Gminski was in the White House until midnight last night. This little pelican thing has then scared. The President wants us to _ secretly investigate it. He wants to know there's nothing to it so he can convince Voyles to back off.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: There's probably nothing to it.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Voyles is just having a little fun with the President and Coal? He neatly places the banana peel in the paper bag and takes out a sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: What did Gminski tell the President? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: That it would be illegal, but in the light of all their pressure, etc. etc. and he sent me off to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Voyles appreciates it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby and Callahan at dinner. In the b.g. we hear an old record of BILLIE HOLLIDAY singing “Lover Man.”

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: (quite pissed) IL have decided my agenda for the future. I plan to stay in bed, drink, make love and forget the whole damned mess. That's an invitation, my dear. If you love me.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: Is it love? Or just a severe case of savior complex suffered by the ambitious young?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: . CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, Darby. What's happened to your sense of humor? A waiter comes over to them. WAITER. Can I tempt you with dessert?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Just coffee.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: Cognac. A double, if you please. The waiter leaves.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I'm driving. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: Oh, come off it. I'm as sober as... (he snorts) A judge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Callahan and Darby emerge from the restaurant. He pulls the car keys from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Please, darling. Give me the keys. Callahan grips them and staggers on into the parking lot. She catches up to hin.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Just give me the keys. Or I’m walking.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN
dialogues.text: Then have a nice walk.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Thomas! Please! Let me drive! He ignores her, walking unsteadily to the car. He un- locks the door, squeezes downward, and disappears between the other cars. Darby turns to the street and waves for a cab. The ROAK of Calishan's Porsche, as he guns the ENGINE. She looks back in time to see the explosion, Callahan's Porsche flips upside down, devoured by flames. Darby starts toward it, screaming for Callahan. A second EXPLOSION from inside the firebal) throws her to the ground. She blacks out. : Two men drag Darby by the elbows back to the sidewalk. Sound of SIRENS. A cop falls to his knees and waves & badge under her nose. coP Ma'am, Sergeant Rupert, N.O.P.D. An ambulance is on the way. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Darby stares blankly ¢: hia as a FIRE TRUCK SCREAMS to 4 halt just feet away. She looks back at what little re- mains of the Porsche, pieces of smoldering, twisted metal where there once had been a man and a car. RUPERT pulls her up. Darby manages to regain use of her legs. She and Rupert walk through the crowd to an unmarked cop car. He opens the front door and gingerly places her in the passenger's seat. Another COP squats in the door. He wears jeans and cow- boy boots with pointed toes.

dialogues.speaker: , COP IN COWBOY BOOTS
dialogues.text: Could I have your name?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Darby Shaw. Another COP CAR, one with decals and lights, SQUEALS to a stop in front of Rupert's. Rupert disappears. The Cow- boy Cop closes the door. She lays her head on the driv- er's seat, and curls into a knot. Her eyes close again and she passes out. BLACKNESS... Sound of KNOCKING on a window OVER the blackness.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH WINDOW
dialogues.text: A POLICEMAN in uniform is knocking on the window.

dialogues.speaker: . POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Open the door, lady!

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Darby sits up, opens the door and stumbles out.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAHAN'S CAR
dialogues.text: A solitary fireman hoses down the burnt frame of the Porsche.  33.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Whoever it was never knew what hit him. Is this your car?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: It's Rupert's.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Rupert?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Sergeant Rupert. One of you guys.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Who the hell's Rupert?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: He said he was a cop. He motions to a man in a suit to come over.

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN SUIT
dialogues.text: I'm Lieutenant Olson, New Orleans P.D. (to second cop) Check the plates. The second cop quickly scribbles down the tag number from Rupert's car and calls it in.

dialogues.speaker: ORLEANS
dialogues.text: Olson is’ driving. Darby sits next to him, in shock.

dialogues.speaker: OLSON, (MAN IN SUIT)
dialogues.text: We have no record of a cop named Rupert, there was no cop here with cowboy boots, and the computer has no record of the tag numbers on the car. Must be fake tags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olson leads her into the room, sits her down among the waiting ill and wounded, goes over to talk to the lady behind the window and then returns. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: OLSON
dialogues.text: It'll be a few minutes. Sit tight. I'm gonna move the car, and I'll be back. Olson leaves. Darby closes her eyes. When she opens them, she is look- ing down at:

dialogues.speaker: PAIR OF COWBOY BOOTS AND TIGHT JEANS
dialogues.text: Identical to these worn by one of the fake cops earlier -- in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: EMERGENCY ROOM
dialogues.text: She looks up in fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is someone else.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The fear remains. CAMERA FOLLOWS Darby AS she rises and walks through a pair of double doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby walks off the loading dock into the alley and turns inte the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIGHT ‘ Darby disappears into the groups of people, tourist types and night-time regulars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby enters.  36.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Where is it now?

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: Well, I read it, then sent it to some folks within the Bureau, who showed it to Director Voyles.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Has it been seen outside the FBI?

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: I can't answer that, Darby.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Then I won't tell you what's happened to Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: VERHEERK
dialogues.text: Okay. Yes, it's been seen outside the F.B.I. By whom and by how many, I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He's dead, Gavin. He was murdered around ten last night. Someone planted a car bomb for both of us. I got lucky, but now they're after me. Verheek reaches for a pad by the bed and starts scrib- bling notes.

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: Where are you staying? What's , your phone number?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Not so fast, Gavin.

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: Come on, Darby! Thomas Callahan was my best friend. Give me fifteen minutes and we'll have a dozen agents pick you up. You can't stay on the streets.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Thomas is dead because he talked to you. Tell that to Director Voyles.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A CLICK, as Darby hans up.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: How serious are you taking this pelican thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President is talking to Voyles alone.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: I've assigned fourteen agents in New Orleans. I doubt if there's anything to it, Mr. President, but we've got to check it out.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: I don't have to tell you, Denton, how much this nonsense could hurt if the press found out. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: I just wish you would back off this thing. I mean, what the hell, it's a goose chase.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: Are you asking me to ignore a suspect, Mr. President?

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: Tf the press saw it and started * digging, I'd be crucified.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: So you're asking me to back off? CAMERA MOVES UP the wall TO hidden cameras.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coal languishes in a comfortable chair.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Back off and chase the real suspects. Ignore it for a couple of weeks.  38.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: President and Voyles in the Gval Office on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Your hatchet man Coal has done a number on me with the press. They've eaten my lunch over the security we provided to Rosenberg and Jensen. You get that pit bull off my ass...

dialogues.speaker: ORLEANS
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES IN CLOSE ON the glass and SEES a girl's face scouring the street, her image broken by the reflections in the glass. Her hair is tucked into the hood of a parka, her eyes are hidden behind a pair of aviator sun- glasses and her maekup is quite different from Darby's. But it is Darby.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And I'll forget the pelican theory for a while.

dialogues.speaker: RUBENSTEIN'S CLOTHING STORE
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS OVER the usual street crowd and stops at a short, thick, powerful stump of a man. He stands there, looking at a newspaper; but his eyes appear over the newspaper, examining the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY BEHIND GLASS
dialogues.text: She pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: STORE
dialogues.text: Darby exits and loses herself in the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gavin Verheek is talking to Lewis. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: Thomas Callahan, my friend from Tulane who brought me the pelican brief, was blown to bits by a car bomb last night in New Orleans.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: Darby Shaw, the girl who wrote it, was supposed to be in the car when it exploded.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: -I just got off the phone with the Director. Pelican's off our list. If it was ever really on. We're focusing on The Underground Army. Look, when the Director Says put it on a back burner, he means a back burner. But you're free to talk to him. When he gets back in town. PHONE RINGING OVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray is not there. A journalist at the next desk reaches over and picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This is Garcia.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Mr. Grantham’s not here. But he left his car number for you.

dialogues.speaker: CAR PHONE RINGING.
dialogues.text: Gray picks it up. His other hand holds the telephoto finder of a camera to his eye.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH TELEPHOTO FINDER
dialogues.text: A man standing in phone booth a block away. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GARCIA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Grantham?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GARCIA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It's Garcia. I still don't know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: (a reassuring, caring voice) Mr. Garcia, if you remember, I went to jail once rather than reveal a source. I know what hell this has to be for you. But you are clearly a decent man, a good citizen. Do you really think you can live in any kind of peace without revealing what you know?

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: GARCIA listening to Grant's persuasive voice. CAMERA WHIP PANS AWAY FROM Garcia in the phone booth -- and, in a SHOCKING MOVE -- a block WHIPS BY us -- and we STOP ON the Volvo. CAMERA SLAMS INTO a CLOSEUP THROUGH the window of Gray's finger on the camera, as he takes Picture after picture. INT. WHITE HOUSE - COAL’S OFFICE - DAY A young ASSISTANT of Coal, a junior version of his boss, is reading a@ memo. Coal leans back behind his desk, amused.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE, (ASSISTANT)
dialogues.text: Khamel... The most famous assassin in the world.

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: And his links to the Libyans and Palestinians... Have it circulated on every desk in the West Wing. By someone of a neutral stripe totally removed from us. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT, (MAN'S VOICE)
dialogues.text: Unsigned?

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: Unsigned.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: The Phantom Memo rides again.

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: (smiling) By this time tomorrow Voyles will be swearing up and down the leak was not the Bureau's. Of course we won't believe him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bus comes up. It stops. Among the people coming out is Sarge. He passes Gray and, without stopping, slips an envelope in his coat pocket. Gray gets on the bus. It's as if they never met.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH KEEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Smells like a White House plant to me.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGING EDITOR
dialogues.text: Grantham and SMITH KEEN, his editor, are looking at a copy of the phantom memo.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH KEEN
dialogues.text: Someone in the White House of fools, probably Coal, wants the world to know that Khamel has emerged as a suspect, and that he has close ties to countries led by fiery idiots who hate America. And you think we're the idiots who should do it.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Fuck Coal. Just judge it on its merits as a story.  42.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Darby sits on the bed in a new hotel room. She is watching television, a can of mace beside her. Her long red hair is now short and black.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS ANCHOR, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: An article in tomorrow morning's edition of i maintains that, according to unnamed White House sources, the Middle Eastern terrorist, known as Khamel, may be one of those who carried out the assassinations of Justices Rosenberg and Jensen. The article, by reporter Gray Gratham, reports...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of lighted window of Darby's hotel room.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S8.)
dialogues.text: She's watching television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gminski and three AGENTS are in the room. HOOTEN, Gminski's aide and confidant, is looking through the binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: . GMINSKI
dialogues.text: They're looking under rocks. She's using credit cards. She'll be dead in forty-eight hours.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: I'll give her seventy-two.

dialogues.speaker: GMINSKI
dialogues.text: (dismissing agents) We'll meet at six A.M. (to his aide and confidant ) Hooten, stay. The others exit. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GMINSKI
dialogues.text: This means her little brief is directly on point. It could have enormous political repercussions.

dialogues.speaker: HOOTEN
dialogues.text: Are you going to notify the president?

dialogues.speaker: GMINSKI
dialogues.text: Notifying the president means notifying Coal.

dialogues.speaker: HOOTEN
dialogues.text: I understand. (beat) Do we bring her in?

dialogues.speaker: GMINSKI
dialogues.text: We can't go around snatching civilians off the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Then she won't last long.

dialogues.speaker: GMINSKI
dialogues.text: Let's sleep on it. If you can convince me to snatch her, then I'll say do it.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE
dialogues.text: Copies of Soldier of Fortune magazine are scattered around. ‘ Physical workout equipment -- dumbbells, weight etc. -- are stacked on one wall. Coal is talking to a powerfully-built middle-aged man who looks like the ex-Marine he is. His sleeves are rolled up, revealing tattoos. He squeezes a hand and wrist exerciser through the scene. ‘

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: Did you ever run across Khamel, Barr?

dialogues.speaker: BARR
dialogues.text: No. During my C.I.A. days we were sure he was dead. In the early years he was the consummate political terrorist. Now he kills for money. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: I think I know who hired him to kill Rosenberg and Jensen.

dialogues.speaker: BARR
dialogues.text: Can you share this bit of gossip?

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: Not yet. I want you to follow Gray Grantham and find out who he's talking to.

dialogues.speaker: BARR
dialogues.text: Tap tap?

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: His apartment and his car.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BED AND BREAKFAST
dialogues.text: Darby is checking in.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: How do you want to pay? Darby reaches for her American Express card, thinks better of it and puts it back in her bag.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Cash. She is learning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: What did Mr. Voyles say, Verheek?

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Voyles has been unavailable. I'll try to talk to him later today.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I expected more. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There will be a memorial service tomorrow at three on campus, with burial afterward in the city. I'll be there tonight. I think we should meet. Darby, I could save your life.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I don't know. You can't even talk to the director. Where will you stay?

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The Hilton, by the river. Sound of PEOPLE SCREAMING and CHEERING and end of a FOOTBALL GAME in progress over:

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: It is Friday night of a big football game in the Quarter. Half and completely drunken fans are watching the big game on a TV set over the bar, cheering, screaming, and groaning, depending on the fate of the home team. Darby is in a tiny booth in a corner, wearing sunglasses and a hat. She reaches up and stops a girl walking by. It's her old friend, Alice. Alice does not recognize her. Darby reaches and removes the sunglasses. Her eyes are red and tired. Alice sits down opposite her.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I didn't know who else to call. Alice stares at this strange, haunted new version of her friend.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: You got into my apartment? Alice nods, reaches into her purse, takes a printout of the directory from Darby's computer and hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (as Darby studies it) You said there were around forty entries, but, see, there are no more than ten. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gp 46.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That means most of the hard-drive memory is gone. I couldn't find a single floppy disk, and your red expandable files? They were empty. Darby stuffs the printout into a pocket.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: They went to my apartment and erased what they wanted to erase.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Who are these people?

dialogues.speaker: . DARBY
dialogues.text: If you want to help, go to the memorial service tomorrow. Spread the word that I called you from Denver where I'm staying with an aunt with a name you don't know, and that I've dropped out this semester but I'll be back in the spring. I think some people will be listening carefully.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FRENCH QUARTER
dialogues.text: Darby emerges from the kitchen door of the Oyster Bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby walks by CAMERA. CAMERA HOLDS ON her back, as she walks through the crowds. A man comes into the f.g. of the SHOT. He stops. His back, very CLOSE TO the CAMERA, covers three quarters of the SCREEN. She turns the corner. CAMERA STAYS in place. The man follows. His feet come through FRAME, clad in snakeskin cowboy boots.

dialogues.speaker: QUARTER
dialogues.text: Darby walks past a crowded sidewalk cafe. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CAMFRA PANS FROM Darby TO her POV of the cafe. A familiar stocky figure sits in front, Stump. ~ CAMERA STOPS for a split second AT Stump as he drinks his coffee. But in that split second he looks up. CAMERA WHIP PANS back TO Darby as she recognizes him. She keeps walking, but faster now. In back of her, Stump is on his feet and weaving through the tables.

dialogues.speaker: QUARTER
dialogues.text: Darby turns on to Bourbon Street, CAMERA FOLLOWING at her pace. Stump moves INTO the FRAME. He is catching up to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three large young men dressed in a wild assortment of black and gold Saints’ garb make a noisy exit from a bar. Darby runs to then.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (she points at Stump) Help! That man is after me! He's trying to rape me! Please help ne Stump rushes forward. The three Saints step in front of him with folded arms and glowing eyes. CAMERA SLAMS INTO the fray as Stump uses both hands at once: A right to the throat of the first one, and a vicious blow to the mouth of the second. They squeal and fall hard. The first one falls on Stump's right foot and this throws him off. As he yanks his foot away, number three kicks him squarely in the crotch. Stump is history. . Darby eases back into the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: GARCIA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It's Garcia. I'm on the corner of Pennsylvania Avenue and First. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Good. Now take down my license number ‘cause there are a lot of gray Volves. (very slowly) 5676582. I'1l be there in ten minutes. Gray hangs up and runs out the door. The TELEPHONE RINGS. Gray comes back in and picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: GARCIA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I can't go through with it. Grantham falls back into a chair in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: GARCIA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I have a wife and little daughter. There's a chance they know that I know. They've been treating me funny. GRANTHAM . These are the guys in your firm?

dialogues.speaker: GARCIA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Yeah. No. Wait. How'd you know Iwas in a firm? I haven't told you that.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: You go to work too early to be a government lawyer. You're in one of those firms where they expect ' the associates and junior partners to work a hundred hours a week. He hears the CLICK of Garcia HANGING UP. Gray bangs the phone down in disgust. He whirls around in his chair and finds himself facing a mirror.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: (to his image in mirror) You know better than to frighten a@ source. Fuckhead! The PHONE RINGS again. He whirls back and picks it up. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: I know there's a way we can work this out, Garcia.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Garcia?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: (totally let down, he loses it) Shit!

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Shit? Is this Gray Grantham with the Washington Post?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Have you heard of the Pelican Brief?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: The Pelican Brief. No. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It's an unlikely little theory about who killed Rosenberg and Jensen. It was taken to Washington last week by a man named Thomas Callahan, a professor of law at Tulane. He gave it to a friend with the F.B.1I., and it was passed around. Callahan was killed in a car bomb ' Wednesday night in New Orleans. He turns on the lamp and starts to scribble on his pad.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: How de you know all this?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I wrote the brief.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Are you a lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Are you calling from New Orleans? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Don't spend your time digging after me.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM'S MEMO PAD
dialogues.text: As he writes: -- Sounds young, -- mid-twenties? -- Knows law professor... not a lawyer...

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: You need a name.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Call me Pelican. Can you get a list of all major contributor's to the president's last campaign?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: I can have it by this afternoon. (writing) And you know who's done the killing?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: I'm not going to beat around the bush. Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: , Let's take it slow. I'll be in touch.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: When? But she has hung up. He puts down the phone and stares at his pad.

dialogues.speaker: PAD
dialogues.text: Next to "Not a lawyer,” he scribbles, "A student?” He draws the oval outline of a woman's face. The inside of the face remains blank, empty of features. He stares at it and then draws a big question mark inside the face.  51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA looks DOWN AT people streaming into the small chapel for Callahan's memorial service.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS WAY
dialogues.text: Darby looking through binoculars. A half eaten sandwich and two empty containers of coffee are on a table next to her.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH BINOCULARS
dialogues.text: CAMERA PICKS UP Alice and a few other familiar faces, students in his class. CAMERA SWINGS BACK ACROSS the road -- past Gavin Verheek -- and STOPS abruptly ON a man watching the people enter the chapel. It is the short, thick, powerful stump of a Man Darby saw outside Rubenstein and the lobby of the Sheraton.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: -- she puts down the binoculars, revealing the the terror in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.5S.)
dialogues.text: Looking for Mr. Sneller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shadow of a man is over the door. The sound of PAPER BEING SLID ACROSS CARPET. CAMERA PANS DOWN, FOLLOWING the sound, and sees an envelope slide through the crack under the door. A dark complected hand sets a gym bag down on the carpet and reaches for the envelope. CAMERA PANS UP with the man's hand as he opens the envelope, revealing a key and a folded piece of paper inside. Two small phetos slide out and drop to the floor. He kneels down to pick them up. His face comes INTO FRAME. The nose is thicker, the hair curly where it was straight, even the teeth are different in relation to the mouth. But the eyes, though a different color, are the eyes of KHAMEL. -

dialogues.speaker: TWO SMALL YEARBOOK PHOTOGRAPHS OF DARBY
dialogues.text: He picks them up.  52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A student hangout not far from the campus. The crowd is passionate, pissed and rowdy. Verheek looks middle-aged and out of place. A YOUNG MAN and his.girl sit down next to him. He wears a T-shirt with the words "Tulane Law School."

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: (turning to the young man) De you know Darby Shaw?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Why do you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: We need to talk to her. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: We?

dialogues.speaker: F.B.I.
dialogues.text: He pulls a card from his pocket. The student reads it, then hands it back.

dialogues.speaker: / YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: You're a lawyer, net an agent. Why do you want to see Darby Shaw? The bartender eases closer, eavesdropping. so, VERHEEK T need to see her, okay. It's very important. I'11 be at the Hilton for a few days. If you see her, ask her to call. He gives the card to the student,’ who leaves it on the bar and starts talking to his girl. The bartender looks at it with curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are too far away to see anything clearly, until we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oo CLOSE SHOT - GATE Two men manipulate the lock and slip through. They walk 1 up to Grantham's Volvo. One of them opens the car door ¥ with quick, professional skill, while the other pulls o \ a small tool case from his pocket. He opens it and I removes a tiny transmitter he prepares to install.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: , Verheek's card underneath the door. Khamel’s hand comes in and picks it up. CAMERA PULLS BACK and FOLLOWS him : as he picks up the phone. A miniature tape recorder sits next to the phone. b SNELLER (V.0.) : We've made a few phone calls to Washington. He knew Callahan, and ; he might know the girl. It's 1 obvious he's trying to find her. ! ‘ DARBY (V.0.) It's Darby, Gavin. INT. VERHEEK’S ROOM -. NIGHT Verheek sits on the edge of the bed in a towel robe.

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: I had about given up. Tell me where you want to meet, and within an ' hour I'll come get you with three agents.

dialogues.speaker: , DABBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: 1 * I thought the F.B.1. was not involved.

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: It's not involved, yet. But I've got friends. We'll get you , out of the city tonight, and take you to Washington tomorrow. I promise you'll personally meet Voyles, and we'll go from there.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Behind your hotel is a place called . Riverwalk. On the second level is oo a clothing store called Frenchmen's Bend. At noon tomorrow I want you to stand by the entrance. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Wear a black shirt of some type and a red baseball cap and hold a folded newspaper. after five minutes, walk inside the store. I'll find you. You and I, and only you and I, will leave the city. I don't want anyone else to know of this. Agreed?

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: Agreed.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: How tall are you?

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: Five ten.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: How much do you weigh?

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK
dialogues.text: Two hundred, but I plan to lose is.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'll see you tomorrow, Gavin. There is the CLICK of Darby hanging up. CAMERA PANS DOWN WITH Verheek's hand to the phone as he hangs up and EXITS FRAME. CAMERA HOLDS ON the phone. We hear the sound of the SHOWER. CAMERA DROPS DOWN BELOW the table top. Scotch taped to the underside of the table is the miniaturized tape recorder we saw in Khamel's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheek turns off the shower and ‘steps out. He reaches for a towel, starts rubbing his hair dry and walks back into the room. He walks over to the TV and TURNS UP the VOLUME, the towel obscuring his vision. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS him as he falls to the floor. A red spot of blood appears on the white towel and Spreads. And then another and another. But except for the TV, there is no sound. A familiar hand reaches INTO FRAME to Verheek's wrist. CAMERA PANS UP TO Khamel's face as he reassures himself there is no pulse. CAMERA RISES WITH Khamel. In back of him we see the now open closet door. : He walks over to the phone and pulls the miniaturized tecorder out from underneath. He rewinds the tape inside. He presses the PLAY button of the recorder.

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It's Darby, Gavin.

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK'S ROOM
dialogues.text: An ironic smile. The TAPE CONTINUES.

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I had about given up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby is ‘taking a shower.

dialogues.speaker: VERHEEK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Tell me where you want te meet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Khamel's miniature TAPE PLAYER, on top of a bureau. It is PLAYING.

dialogues.speaker: VERHEFK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And within fifteen minutes, I'll come get you with three agents. We'll get you out of the city tonight. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CAMERA ADJUSTS a little to the right. Laying next to the miniature tape player is a tiny gun. Khamel's hand ENTERS FRAME and STOPS the TAPE RECORDER. CAMERA PANS UP to see Khamel putting an extra large black Sweatshirt over his head. He is wearing layers of briefs and gym shorts to give him the appearance of Verheek's weight.

dialogues.speaker: KHAMEL
dialogues.text: (imitating Verheek quite brilliantly) And within fifteen minutes, I'll come get you with three agents. He puts on a red baseball cap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby stands before a mirror, dressing.

dialogues.speaker: KHAMEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (sounding like Verheek) We'll get you out of the city tonight. And take you to Washington tomorrow. Darby exits. KHAMEL’S ROOM - CLOSE SHOT - TINY GUN ON BUREAU TOP - DAY Khamel picks it up. CAMERA FOLLOWS the gun as it disappears INTO his trouser pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby walking in the middle of a group of shoppers, browsing. She looks at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: WATCH
dialogues.text: Tt is exactly twelve o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: She looks up.  57.

dialogues.speaker: BEND
dialogues.text: There he is, black sweatshirt, red baseball cap, folded newspaper. The eyes are hidden behind sunglasses. He looks at his watch, then walks through the door.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: as he picks through safari jackets.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Gavin. He jerks around.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: She is holding a white Panama hat and speaking into it.

dialogues.speaker: HE
dialogues.text: (pulling out a handkerchief and sneezing) (coughing) Wouldn't you know I'd wake up with a cold. Darby.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Follow me. They leave the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby takes his hand. They walk quickly down a flight of stairs leading to the boardwalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boardwalk is crowded; 2 line has formed beside the Bayou Quean, « paddle wheeler. They stop at the end of the line.

dialogues.speaker: HE
dialogues.text: Are we getting on this boat?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Yes. I've got a car a mile upriver at a park where we'll stop in thirty minutes. The line is moving now.  58.

dialogues.speaker: HIM
dialogues.text: * CAMERA FOLLOWS his hand as he touches the trouser pocke that contains the gun. He reaches into the Pocket and pulls out a handkerchief. CAMERA PANS UP WITH him as he brings it to his nose. There is a tiny flash of metal against the base of his skull just below the red baseball cap.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY'S HAND
dialogues.text: holding his as his hand falls away from hers.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: as she whirls around.

dialogues.speaker: HIM
dialogues.text: falling to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE HANDKERCHIEF
dialogues.text: still clutched in his hand as it hits the ground. It turns blood red.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY'S EYES AND MOUTH
dialogues.text: FILLING the SCREEN with her scream... She whirls around in horrer,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aman is running away. He disappears in a crowd.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He's got a gun. CAMERA WHIRLS BACK again, FOLLOWING the sound of the woman's voice. She is standing next to Darby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mon she thinks is Verheek is or all fours with a small pistol in his right hand. Blood streams from his chin and puddles under his face. He lunges to the edge of the boardwalk. The gun drops into the water. He collapses on his stomach with his head hanging over and dripping into the river.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: As two policemen break through to get to him. A hundred people now inch forward to see the dead man. But there is no sign of Darby. The sound of a CAR SCREECHING to a stop OVER.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: braking his cab. TIGHT ON the driver as a passenger gets in.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Baton Rouge.

dialogues.speaker: CAB DRIVER
dialogues.text: Lord, honey, that’s a heckuva ride. He angles his rearview mirror to see Darby, hidden under anew hat and black trench coat. She is wearing new sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: ‘How much?

dialogues.speaker: CAB DRIVER
dialogues.text: (thinking quickly) A hundred and fifty. She throws two bills over the seat.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: There's two hundred. Get there as fast as you can, and watch your rear. We may be followed.

dialogues.speaker: BACK SEAT TAKI
dialogues.text: Darby lies down on the seat.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Whoever killed Verheek didn't leave a trace.  60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Director Voyles stands behind his chair. K.Q. Levis sits across the desk.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: I'm sending a hundred agents in tomorrow to blanket the city and I've instructed New Orleans to find the girl, if she's scill alive.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Gavin told me about Callahan, and I didn’t listen.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: And I thought this Pelican stuff was some bird brained joke. (beat) We'll spend two thousand hours digging round that hotel, and I'll bet you there won't be a shred of useful evidence. Just like Rosenberg and Jensen.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: And Callahan.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: And probably the girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby curled up on the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we ever find her body.

dialogues.speaker: TAXI DRIVER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Here we are, ma'am. Baton Rouge Airport. And in record time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She immerses herself in a group of people walking into the airport.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Can't you bring her in?  61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man we saw earlier sitting on @ circular bench is sitting there again. The Man from Langley sits near him on the bench.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: We lost her at O'Hara in Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Let's hope they did too.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (through phone) There's been another murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on his desk. He is riffling through it, looking for a fresh page. In the process, we see page after page of his sketches of what the Pelican might look like. He finds a fresh page and begins to scribble notes.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (through phone) You remember I told you Callahan gave a copy of the brief to a friend at the F.B.I.?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM ON PHONE
dialogues.text: scribbling notes.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (through phone) He was killed yesterday in New Orleans. GRANTHAM . How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (through phone) I was holding his hand when he was shot. In broad daylight in the middle of a crowd. God knows how I got away.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Can you give me his name? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (through phon.) Verheek. Gavin Verheek.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Voyles' chief counsel.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (through phone) When can you come to New York?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Right now.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Let's plan on tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Day

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You must follow my instructions. A cab pulls up. Gray jumps out with his bag. He is wearing sunglasses. He checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: WATCH
dialogues.text: Te reads 10:46 A.M.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Gray enters the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray sits there with a Coke. He looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: WATCH
dialogues.text: It reads 11:30 A.M. He reaches for his wallet and pays the check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray hails a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cab pulls up. Gray gets out and disappears in the throng of shoppers.  63.

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: He enters on the Fifth Avenue side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits the hotel and walks west on Central Park South.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ducks through the service entrance.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
