dialogues.text: (to clerk behind the counter) I have a reservation. Warren Clark.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM'S HAND
dialogues.text: Sketching the unknown Darby, based on his fantasy of her.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: He picks up the phone with remarkable alacrity.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Clark?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Yea. This is Mr. Clark.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Take the elevator to the eighteenth, then walk down to the fifteenth. Room. 1520.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM DOOR
dialogues.text: The room number 1520 displayed prominently across the oor. Gray's fist COMES INTO the SHOT and knocks on the door. Sound of BOLT CLICK. The door opens a smidgen, the chain still on. Darby's eye appears at the opening.  64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helf of Gray's face through the erack in the door.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Pelican?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY'S EYE
dialogues.text: Peering through the crack. The door shuts again, the sound of the CHAIN being UNLATCHED, and the door opens all the way, revealing Gray's first full look at Darby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small sitting room with a door to small bedroom. He enters; she quickly shuts the door. She locks the door and bolts it.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: You followed my instructions?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: (trying to break the tension) I haven't ducked and feinted, backed up and reversed myself so much since I played quarterback in college.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: You must think I'm crazy.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: ‘ That was a possibility, until I checked New Orleans. Callahan was killed exactly as you said. I also checked on Verheek. According to the FBI, his body was found the day before yesterday in his hotel room very early in the morning. Darby looks stunned.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: He'd been dead for at least eight hours.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: That can't be. He talked like Verheek, he followed my instructions to the letter... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: An imposter.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Who planned to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Until someone killed him first. (gently) Why don’t you sit down and teil me what was in the brief.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Everyone I've spoken to about the brief is dead.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: I'll take my chances.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Just to get a story.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: This isn't any story.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: You will net, under any circumstances, use my name, or reveal where or how you got the information. And you will not publish it until I leave the country. Agreed?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Agreed. We don't publish without ‘specific confirmation. That can take quite a while to get. TE ever. He reaches for his briefcase. GRANTHAM . (taking out a mini tape recorder) Do you mind if I use a tape recorder?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: No. There should be a record. I may not be around. He puts the tape recorder on the coffee table in front of Darby. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Ready. He starts the tape recorder and leans back in his chair, pen in hand and a clean legal pad on his lap.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Does the name, Mattiece, mean anything to you?

dialogues.speaker: COPY OF DARBY'S ORIGINAL BRIEF
dialogues.text: The Pelican Brief -- being held in someone's hand. INT. COAL’S LIMOUSINE (WASHINGTON) - NIGHT Coal and MATTHEW BARR in the back seat. Barr finishes reading the Brief and looks at Coal.

dialogues.speaker: BARR
dialogues.text: What did the President say?

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: It's just another wild shot in the dark, we thought. He talked to Voyles about it, and Voyles agreed to leave it alone for a while. Now I'm not so sure.

dialogues.speaker: BARR
dialogues.text: ‘The President asked Voyles to back off? coaL Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BARR
dialogues.text: That's obstruction of justice, assuming of course the Brief turns out to be true.

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: And if it does?

dialogues.speaker: BARR
dialogues.text: You'll be forced to be the fall guy and resign. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: Hell, everyone in the White, House, except the President, will have to go. And he'll go soon enough.

dialogues.speaker: BARR
dialogues.text: The Nixon route. cOAL Don't even think that name.

dialogues.speaker: . BARR
dialogues.text: Look at the hopeful side: Irangste, Iraggate. There's a very good chance it won't come out.

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: Grantham knows about the Brief. He called three White House aides yesterday. And god knows who else

dialogues.speaker: BARR
dialogues.text: We got his car phone, but we haven't been inside his apartment yet.

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: BARR
dialogues.text: We almost got caught this morning by his cleaning lady. We'll try again tonight. Someone we know ‘at the Poat says he'll be out of town until tomorrow. The closeup sound of an ALARM OVER.

dialogues.speaker: TAPE RECORDER PLAYING
dialogues.text: The alara is the BEEP of the TAPE RECORDER as it reaches the end of the tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ff the recorder. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: hat made you hone in so quickly on this particular case?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Of course it was luck. Bad luck, it now turns out. T remembered a piece "Frontline" did about a year ago. They interviewed the young lawyer who originally filed the suit. They said, that since the interview, he had committed suicide, although his family insisted it was foul play. After the assassinations I called his family. They said he'd had 2 depressive problem years before, but that he'd been fine since taking medication. His doctors confirmed everything the family said. They told the police they were convinced that it was not 4& suicide.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: But the police had closed the investigation.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: I'm glad you're not my competition. (looking at her exhausted face) ‘when was the last time you really slept?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I don't remember. She studies him as he gathers up ‘the tape recorder and the tape and puts it in his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: If I'd known what was going to happen, I would never have pursued it. But you do, and it doesn't stop you. Why take such a chance?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: It's my kind of high. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I still don't uaderstand.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Well, my editor, Smith Keen, says you've got to have a quirk to do this kind of work. You have to get a special kick from exposing the high and mighty when they try to put one over.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: No matter what the cost?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Let's say it helps to have gotten a few swift, unfair kicks when you were very young. He goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Call me when you wake up. I den't plan to sleep much tonight. I want to make my notes while it's all fresh. He goes over to the door.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (hesitant) Gray? , He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: ‘Would you mind sleeping on the sofa? I know it sounds dumb put...

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: No problem. She starts to exit to the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: At the risk of sounding old- fashioned, if I'm going to spend the night, don't you think it's time I knew your name? She smiles. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: My name is Darby. Shaw. He looks at her; underneath the Strength, vulnerable, touching, and, oh, Lord, desirable.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: How'd you happen to pick me, Darby Shaw?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Callahan was a fan.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: And you were a fan of Callahan's.

dialogues.speaker: . DARBY
dialogues.text: He was the only man I've ever loved. (reacting to Gray's clear attraction) Still do.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: (as he gets the message) Right. She exits to the bedroom and shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby walks over to the mirror. The face that looks back at her appears almost relaxed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray sits at the desk, his laptop and the tape recorder before hin.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM'S HAND
dialogues.text: As he turns on the tape recorder. CAMERA MOVES UP TO his wrist. His watch says 12:20 A.M.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (from the tape recorder) Does the name Mattiece mean anything to you?  9 71.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER MAN'S HAND
dialogues.text: As it reaches for a file. The watch on his wrist also says 12:20 A.M.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: First thing that comes to mind is rich. Victor... His name is Victor Mattiece?

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Coal reaching for the file.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Correct. Victor Mattiece. WHITE HOUSE - COAL'S OFFICE - COAL'’S POV OF OPEN FILE -

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: A clipping headlined PRESIDENT'S BANQUET FOR TOP CONTRIBUTORS, contains a photograph of a beaming Presi- dent shaking hands with a big, distinguished- looking gray-haired man. The caption reads: Happy President and Oil Tycoon Friend, Victor Mattiece.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He's made and lost several fortunes drilling for oil in south Louisiana. CAMERA MOVES INTO a CLOSER SHOT of the two beaming faces.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: "| In 1979, his oil company punched some holes in Terrebonne Parish and hit oil. A lot of oil. He capped the wells before word leaked out... CAMERA PANS OVER the photograph TO a CLOSEUP SHOT of the President's beaming face. :

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .». And bought the surrounding land under a myriad of corporate names. He knew he'd need government permission to dredge a channel through the marshlands to get the equipment in and the oil out. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Entec Mattiece, the Great Campaign Contributor, and, as night must follow day, government permission to gouge through the endangered marshes. CAMERA PANS OVER the photograph to a CLOSEUP SHOT of Mattiece's beaming face.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Mattiece is that close to at least a billion: dollars, when Green Fund, an obscure environmental outfit, trots on down to the U.S. District court in Lafayette, and files a lawsuit to stop the entire operation. A federal judge halts the project pending a trial on ail issues. Of course Mattiece spares no expense to win the lawsuit. I don't think there's a top law firm between Houston and New Orleans that at some point he hasn't hired.

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: Studying the buddy-buddy picture of Mattiece and the President. His face is a study in agony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the time the Green Fund lawyers, -- all two of them -- wade in, the joint ventures, limited ‘| partnerships and corporate associations form an impenetrable maze that make Mattiece invisible. Coal removes the photograph and studies the papers underneath.

dialogues.speaker: COAL'S WHITE HOUSE OFFICE
dialogues.text: INSERT of the papers in the file. A series of Louisiana newspaper clippings about the lawsuit and the trial. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luckily for Green Fund's 1 ewauit, the heart of the new oil reserve is near a natural refuge for waterflow. Osprey, egrets, pelicans, ducks, cranes, geese. Coal removes the clippings to reveal a video cassette of a "Frontline" telecast titled: Oil vs. The Louisiana Pelican

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: looking at the "Frontline" cassette.

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: (to himself) Fucking P.B.S.! He pushes the cassette aside.

dialogues.speaker: , DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The pelican becomes the hero. After thirty years of contamination by D.D.T. and other pesticides, the Louisiana brown pelican perches on the brink of extinction. Green Fund seizes the majestic bird, and enlists experts from around the country to testify on its behalf. COAL’S WHITE HOUSE OFFICE - WIDE ANGLE SHOT - NIGHT Coal gets up and paces up and down his office, trying to develop some kind of plan.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It takes seven years for the Pelican Suit to go to trial in Lake Charles. The three man jury, about the pelican than jobs, votes in favor of Mattiece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coal looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: COAL'S WATCH
dialogues.text: It reads 12:30 A.M. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DANTY (¥.0.) But the judge rules to keep the injunction against drilling in place because he thinks Green Fund has proven its point about the pelican, a federally protected species, and it's apparent that Green Fund will appeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It reads 12:31 A.M.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ‘What's the status of the lawsuit? CAMERA PANS UP TO the man's face. It is one of the men we saw bugging the phone in Gray's car. He looks out the window of the van.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: From the trial level it will be appealed to the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals in New Orleans in about a month. EXT. GRANTHAM APARTMENT HOUSE - MAN IN VAN’S POV about a half a block away.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Any idea what the Fifth Circuit might do? waar (WASHINGTON) - CLOSE SHOT OF MAN WATCHING - N . The CAMERA PANS OVER TO the man sitting next to him as he turns to him. It is the same man we saw with hin when he bugged Gray's car.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It could be reversed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men, carrying dispatch cases, as if they've just come from working late at the office, quietly leave their car.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Then the fun starts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: facing the entrance doo.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: If either side is unhappy with the Fifth Circuit, they can appeal to the Supreme Court. THE SOUND OF A WINDOW BEING JIMMED OPEN... The CAMERA PANS AROUND, FOLLOWING the sound. It arrives at the window just after it has been opened. The curtains blow but no one is there.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: From today, how long would it take for the case to be decided by the Supreme Court? The figure of the first man climbs through the window. And then the second.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Anywhere from three to five years. CAMERA FOLLOWS the two men as they check the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Rosenberg would have died from natural causes.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Yes, but another President could be in the White House when he died. The two men stop at the phone in Gray's apartment.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: So, if you're Victor Mattiece, and you don't mind killing a couple of Supremes, now is the time to take him out, when you can predict his replacement. GRANTHAM'’S APARTMENT - CLOSE SHOT OF ONE OF MEN'S DISPAT

dialogues.speaker: CASES
dialogues.text: One of the men opens it, revealing tools to bug the phone

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But why Jensen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the two men, clearly superb professionals, go about their job of bugging Gray's phones. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DARBY (v.u.) He shared one piece of common ground with Rosenberg: Protecting the environment. The BEEP sound of the TAPE RECORDER coming to the end of a tape comes over.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Tired?

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Gray turns off the tape recorder and sits back in his chair. He looks at the notes he has made on his laptop and writes:

dialogues.speaker: SCREEN OF GRANTHAM'S LAPTOP
dialogues.text: as he writes: "WHERE DOES GARCIA FIT IN? DOES HE?" sound of a MOTOR STARTING OVER the computer screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The VAN STARTS UP. It comes CLOSE TO CAMERA, just long enough to see the smiling faces of the two men we had left in Gray's apartment, before it PASSES OUT OF FRAME. CAMERA HOLDS ON the street: Bars closing, people straggling out, some drifting into an all night coffee shop. :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bland, small man of indeterminate age, distinguished from the drinkers drifting in by his sobriety. He walks over to the counter and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.5S.)
dialogues.text: So, what's the score? CAMERA PANS OVER TO the man on the stool next to him, “Sergeant Rupert”, the man who told Darby he was a cop. and then disappeared. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: NONDESCRIPT MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We can't find her. And that worries us because we got some bad news today. CAMERA PULLS BACK to include the two of them.

dialogues.speaker: NONDESCRIPT MAN
dialogues.text: We hear, unconfirmed, that the bad guy's are sending in big boys with big guns.

dialogues.speaker: . RUPERT
dialogues.text: So, what's my plan?

dialogues.speaker: NONDESCRIPT MAN
dialogues.text: If we find the girl, it'll be your show.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY'S HOTEL SUITE, (NEW YORK)
dialogues.text: Gray is asleep on the couch. The laptop is literally on his lap and a big yellow legal pad with notes is in his hand. : He opens his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CLOSE SHOT
dialogues.text: showered and dressed, Looking down at him.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You said Mattiece hired law firms ' from Houston to New Orleans. Were there any from D.C.?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: You're half asleep.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: rises, rubbing sleep from his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I can think of two: White and Blazevich and Brim, Stearns, and somebody both old, big, powerful, and rich. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: A lawyer in D.C. called me, said he saw something concerning Rosenberg and Jensen. We were supposed to meet, but he bombed out, and I haven't heard from him again. He gave me a phoney name, but I got his picture.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: That's another story. If he works for either of those firms, he could be our confirmation.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I hope you find him.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Darby, come with me to Washington. I need your heip.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Of course you do. If I disappear, you may not have a story. But I might have a life.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: If you're right about Mattiece, there'll be a coverup, and the odds are it'll work. Oh, there'll be a cottage industry of books and articles and movies about the assassinations -- as there was with “Kennedy's: But no one will be prosecuted,

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Why are you so sure? GRANTHAM . T checked the Post morgue last night. On Mattiece. Two years ago we ran a big, fat, front page picture of the President with his arm around Mattiece. He contributed the absolute top limit to his campaign. If what you say is true ’ the President is history I know Coal, the man who pulls the strings that made him President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They won't let that happen. They'll weave a coverup that'll make Watergate look like kiddies playing hide and seek.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: It didn't work with Watergate.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Oh, Darby. Don't you know that for every Watergate that comes to light, there are more that never surface? The word goes out and suddenly things that happened didn't happen, and evidence that was no longer is. You will be the only witness to the murders that connect the assassinations to your Brief. Disappear and so will justice. Is that what Callahan would want?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Thomas would want me to see my twenty-fifth birthday. Even my thirtieth. (beat) Ga back to Washington, Gray. And be careful. I'd miss your byline.

dialogues.speaker: OF GRANTHAM'S BAG

dialogues.text: You'll call?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I may decide to hop a plane and disappear. .

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: You are a tough one. ‘DARBY Thank the Lord. He goes over to her to kiss her good-bye, but she pulls away. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Don't you understand? Rage is all that keeps me going. He leaves, shutting the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'll wait until I hear the bolt. She goes to the door and bolts it. She leans against the door, not tough at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby sits on a bench next to a young WOMAN holding a reflector underneath her chin. She closes her eyes and turns her face into the sun, reaching for sustenance from its warmth. She opens her eyes. Warmth turns to horror.

dialogues.speaker: DAY

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: ‘| You've got some nerve!

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Please. There's a man, a stumpy, stocky man. Has he walked by?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Please. Please. Tell me when he's Past. He's been harassing me.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray is driving. Darby settles into her seat, as he pulls away. :

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: (going over the list) Our last hope, our best hope, Edward Linney, wasn't home.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: What's his class schedule?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Shit, I didn't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. REGISTRAR’S OFFICE - DAY Gray flashes a smile to the Registrar. A STUDENT is going over files in back of her.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Hi, here I am again. I need another class schedule. For Edward Linney.

dialogues.speaker: REGISTRAR
dialogues.text: Sorry. One of the students you talked to this morning called White and Blazevich and they called the assistant dean. No more class schedules will be given to reporters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray comes out and makes his way to the entrance to the building.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Grantham. Gray turns around and sees the Student who worked in the Registrar's office running towards him.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: I know Edward. He's sort of dropped out of school for a while. Personal problems.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: ‘His parents put him in a private hospital. He's being detoxified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A detox center for the rich, it is a small building sur- rounded by trees and sitting alone, a half-mile off the highway. Gray parks the car outside the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray enters the lobby and goes over to the RECEPTIONIST.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: I'm here to see Edward Linney. What room is he in? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: And who might you be?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: (the warm and friendly Gray) Gray Grantham, with the Washington They told me at the law school I could ask him a couple of questions.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I'm sorry they told you that. You see, Mr. Grantham, we run this hospital, and they run their law school. Darby enters the lobby in the background. Gray stands so that the Receptionist doesn't see her.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Could I see the administrator?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: You may have a seat.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Thank you. She leaves and Gray turns to Darby. Darby walks through @ pair of double doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby walks down the corridor, checking the names of the patients on the doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very bureaucratic ADMINISTRATOR is talking to Gray.

dialogues.speaker: ADMINISTRATOR
dialogues.text: Mr...

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Grantham.

dialogues.speaker: ADMINISTRATOR
dialogues.text: Yes... Visitation is only allowed on Saturdays and Sundays, and then only family.  107.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby stops at @ door with the name Edward Linney on it. She knocks.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: When do you expect Mr. Linney to be discharged?

dialogues.speaker: ADMINISTRATOR
dialogues.text: I'm afraid that is absolutely confidential. Gray gives a furtive glance towards the door behind which Darby disappeared. He is clearly stalling.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Probably when his insurance expires.

dialogues.speaker: ADMINISTRATOR
dialogues.text: (enraged) What?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (0.5S.)
dialogues.text: Do you recognize this man? INT. EDWARD L. LINNEY’S ROOM - DAY EDWARD LINNEY, a rather delicate young man, looks at the photo is Darby’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: LINNEY
dialogues.text: What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (discouraged) — That's the whole point. We don't know.

dialogues.speaker: LINNEY
dialogues.text: He works in the oil and gas section on the ninth floor. What is his name? Darby practically holds her breath. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LINNEY
dialogues.text: Morgan. Yep, Morgan. His first name is something like Charles, but that's not it.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I can’t tell you how grateful I am.

dialogues.speaker: LINNEY
dialogues.text: You know, when you opened the door, I thought I was hallucinating again.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: {as she backs away from the bed) I'm really sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LINNEY
dialogues.text: Oh, no. I°11l take a hallucination like that any time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby comes out of the room and quietly closes the door behind her. She scoots toward the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: (from behind her) Hey! You! Darby turns and faces a tall SECURITY GUARD with a gun on his hip. The door doorway.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: (as he backs her into the wall) What're you doing? DARBY . You scared me. I was visiting my brother.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: Who's your brother?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Edward Linney... to Linney's room opens, revealing Linney in the (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: This your sister? Darby leads with her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LINNEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, leave her alone.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Mom will be up this weekend.

dialogues.speaker: LINNEY
dialogues.text: And Sarah?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Yes, Edward?

dialogues.speaker: LINNEY
dialogues.text: (really meaning it) You come back soon.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I'll try.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: (to Administrator) IT hate to sound preachy, but I know you agree with me about the horrendous cost of health care.

dialogues.speaker: ADMINISTRATOR
dialogues.text: Of course, of course. Darby enters quickly through the doors, and is almost to the front deor when the Administrator sees her.

dialogues.speaker: ADMINISTRATOR
dialogues.text: Miss! Oh, miss! Can I have your name? . Darby is out the front door. Gray shrugs at the Administrator and casually leaves the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS their Hertz Pontiac. Gray is driving lize a bat out of hell. The CAMERA lets Gray's car SLIDE OUT OF FRAME. Another car appears in back of them. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CAMERA ZOOMS IN, revealing Rupert behind the wheel. He is holdin, + phone with his othar hand.

dialogues.speaker: RUPERT
dialogues.text: (inte phone) I got ‘em!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray holding the phone to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I find no listing for a Curtis Morgan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray enters the car. He starts it quickly.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: No luck. He must be unlisted. (looking at his watch) It's quarter till four. We'll have to hurry.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Into the eye of the storm. If we ‘can make it before closing.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: White and Blazevich? They'll know who you are.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: That's true. :

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: And what if they associate me with the inquiry at Georgetown?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: We're talking about getting by a receptionist who doesn’t have the least idea of anything that's going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: lll.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Maybe we better think about this some more.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Okay. We'll think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RECEPTIONIST sits before a wall with the name WHITE AND BLAZEVICH emblazoned in brass letters.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: May I help you?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: My name is Dorothy Blythe. I have a five o'clock appointment with Curtis Morgan. . The Receptionist looks stunned.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Is something the matter?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Just a moment. She stands quickly, and disappears in a rush. Darby has a moment of terror, not sure if she should run and cut her losses. A MAN of about fifty comes over to her, followed by the Receptionist.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: You say you have an appointment with Curtis Morgan?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Yes. At five.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (inching closer) When did you make the appointment?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: About two weeks ago. If met Curtis at a party in Georgetown. He told me he as an oil and gas lawyer, and I happen to need one. (CONTINUED )
The elevator door opens, and SCHWABE, a man in a cheap suit approaches quickly to juin the conversation. Darby scowls at him.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWABE
dialogues.text: Curtis Morgan is dead.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: My God, he was such a young man! Why didn't anyone call me?

dialogues.speaker: SCHWABE
dialogues.text: We have no record of an appointment with a Dorothy Blythe.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: What happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: SCHWABE
dialogues.text: He was mugged a week ago. Shot by street punks, we believe. The guy in the cheap suit takes a step closer.

dialogues.speaker: SCWABE
dialogues.text: Do you have any identification?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Who in the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: SCHWABE
dialogues.text: He's security.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Security for what? Is this a law ‘ firm or a prison?

dialogues.speaker: SCHWABE
dialogues.text: Why don't you leave, Ms. Blythe?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Io can't wait! The security Man reaches to assist her.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (reaching to assist her) Here. Darby slaps his hand. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Touch me and I'll sue your ass first thing tomorrow morning. The men are a bit shaken.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I'll see you down.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I know how to leave. (stepping backward) I paid a half a million last year in legal fees. She is now in the corner of the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: And I've got a million to pay next year, but you idiots won't get it. The closer she gets to the elevator, the louder she yells. . The Security Man is at the elevator now, holding the door open for her. They watch her until the elevator door shuts on her and she is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby runs out of the elevator and runs right into a big distinguished middle-aged man who is waiting to enter the elevator. The CAMERA SLAMS INTO his face as Darby hits him. Their eyes face right into each other. It is Sneller. Darby, of course, has no idea who he is. And, at first, Sneller, in his surprise, has no idea who she is. He walks into the elevator. As the doors start to shut, it hits him. He runs out of the elevator. SNELLER'’S POV Darby running to Gray's rented car. Gray, seeing her terror, STARTS the MOTOR. She jumps into the CAR and he's off. Gray SCREECHES to a stop at the exit and hands the attendant his ticket and a bill and races out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAR ROARS: down the street, slows abruptly and whirls into an alley.  ——— 114.

dialogues.speaker: DESERTED BACK ALLEY
dialogues.text: The CAR comes to a SCREECHING halt. Darby jumps out and throws up against a wall. : Gray gets out of the car and goes over to her. She starts to sob uncontrollably. He reaches out to take her in his arms. But lunging wildly, violently, she pushes, then kicks him away. He stands there helplessly, as she continues sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray paces along the end of the bed, holding the phone. Darby is stretched out on the bed, her eyes closed.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH KEEN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We ran a story about a young lawyer who was robbed and shot about a week ago. I'11 check it out.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: I need his wife's name and address, if we have it.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH KEEN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'll call you back. What's your number?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: T'll call you. He hangs up. He goes over to the bed and sits down next to her. ¢ Now look me in the face. She looks at him. He's very serious.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: It's time for you to leave.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: And if you need confirmation for the story?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: I'm on my own. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: What's changed your mind?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: I want you to reach 25, my love. He picks up the phone and punches a number.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Sorry, that's the second time. (into phone) Smith, it's Gray.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH KEEN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I've got the obit here. The usual -unsolved mugging stuff. TI got the widow's address from the guys who cover police. Priscilla Morgan, 225 Willow Road, Bethesda.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: (writing) 225 Willow Road.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH KEEN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Make sure you report in before noon tomorrow. We're nervous over here. (beat) You know, Grantham, good help is hard to find. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I'm going with you.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: It's too risky, Darby. What if they're watching the house?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: It's a little late for:you to bring up risks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray with Darby. He rings the doorbell. The door opens slightly.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MAN
dialogues.text: (from behind the door) Yes. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: I'm Gray Grantham with the Washington Post and this is my ] assistant, Sara Jacobs. Darby smiles reassuringly. Morgan.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MAN
dialogues.text: I'm her father, and she doesn't

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: We would like to speak with Mrs. ! want to talk.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Sir, I respect her privacy, and T know what she's bean through.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MAN
dialogues.text: Since when do you guys respect anyone's privacy?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: \ Her husband called me three times } ~~ before he died. I don't believe : . his death was a random killing by street punks.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MAN
dialogues.text: , My daughter doesn't want to talk. Now get the hell cut of here. He slams the door shut. Gray takes a card out of his pocket. The number of his | hotel and room number are on the back. He slips it un- j derneath the door.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: (through door) If she changes her mind, the number's on the back. Ask for the room number. But please, don't ask for me by name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray is driving.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: I'll try again tomorrow. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LL.”

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She studies the obstinate, relentless determination of his face.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: And tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: And the tomorrow after that. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: We're only fifteen minutes from the airport. You can be out of here in an hour.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby lies in bed, staring at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: After I figure where to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray lies in bed, staring at the ceiling. The PHONE RINGS. He picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Grantham?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (interrupting) This is Mrs. Morgan.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: (controlling his excitement ) I'm sorry if we upset you. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A look of

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MORGAN, (WOMAN)
dialogues.text: My father is very protective. The reporters were awful after Curtis was killed.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Did you know he called me?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MORGAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: No. What did he say to you?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: He said he knew something about the assassinations of Justices Rosenberg and Jensen. We had planned to meet, but he called and said no. He was scared, and said he had to protect his family. Did you know any of this?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MORGAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: No. bitter disappointment crosses Gray's face. MRS. MORGAN (v.0.) How would he know anything about those dead judges?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Mrs. Morgan, I wish I knew. Where did he keep his valuable papers?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MORGAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We have a lockbox at the bank for deeds and wills and stuff. I * looked at it last Thursday with my father, and there was nothing unusual in it. Then Saturday morning, I was going through his papers in his desk in the bedroom and I found something a bit unusual. A key.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: A key to what?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MORGAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Another lockbox.

dialogues.speaker: ' GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Which bank? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Silence. 119.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MORGAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: First Columbia. We've never banked there.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: I see. And you knew nothing about this other lockbox?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MORGAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Not until Saturday morning. I found all of our legal papers in the old lockbox, so I had no reason to check this one. I figured I'd run by when I felt up to it. On top of everything else, I'm battling flu.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Would you like me to check it for you?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: There could be a clue to who killed your husband.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Mrs. Morgan, we could be running out of time.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MORGAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: T would think they wouldn't give it ‘to anybody but his wife. But my father said your partner is a woman.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: And totally trustworthy.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MORGAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I would have one condition. If you find some thing that disparages my husband in any way, you can't use it.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: It's a deal. I swear. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MORGAN, (V.Q.)
dialogues.text: I think you should know that our bank froze our bex as soon as they learned of Curtis’ death, and that I was allowed only to view the contents and make an inventory. The box will be released to me enly after the tax auditors finish their work.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Of course, you don't know whether or not First Columbia knows Curtis is dead.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MORGAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I have no idea. Do you want the key?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Do. you have it in your hand? He gets up and starts to dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sneller sits in a chair, his eyes kept at the view through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby enters the revolving doors into a lobby as big as a football field.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (to a young woman at the information desk) Safe deposit boxes? The girl points to a corner in the far right. Darby gets up to a set of massive bronze doors. To the left, an important-looking lady of sixty sits behind a desk with the words SAFE DEPOSIT BOXES across its front.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (to woman) T need access to a box. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WOMAN te {turning to her computer keyboard) The number, please.

dialogues.speaker: F566.
dialogues.text: The Woman punches the number and waits for the words to flash on the screen. She frowns, and moves her face to within inches of it.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: That was rented two weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I assume you're Mrs. Morgan.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Yes, Beverly Anne Morgan.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: And your address?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: 891 Pembroke, Alexandria. She pecks again.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Phone number?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Who rented this box? DARBY . My husband, Curtis D. Morgan.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: And his social security number? Darby casually opens her bag and pulls out her wallet.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (as if reading from @ card inside the wallet) 510-96-8686. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Woman places a wide card on a small clipboard on the desk, and points at it.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Sign here, Mrs. Morgan. Darby signs on the second slot. The Woman glances at the signature.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Do you have your key?

dialogues.speaker: . DARBY
dialogues.text: Of course. The Woman takes a small box from the drawer, and walks around the desk.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Follow me. They go through the bronze doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vault is a maze of hallways and small chambers. Two men in uniform walk by. Darby follows the Woman into one of the rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Woman goes over to F566 and sticks in the key. Darby inserts her key next to the other one. The Woman turns both keys, and slides the box two inches from its slot. She removes the bank key.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (pointing to a small bocth) When you finish, lock it back in Place and come to my desk.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Thanks. The Woman leaves. Darby slides the box from the wall.

dialogues.speaker: BOX
dialogues.text: Inside there are two items; a thin, brown legal-sized envelope and an unmarked videotape.  123.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: She stuffs the envelope and videctap: ir. her shoulder bag, slides the box back into its slot, and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby opens the door to the car and gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He STARTS the CAR and speeds away. She takes the envelope out of her purse and opens it. She pulls out a document.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (studying the document ) It's a four page affidavit, sworn to under oath before a notary public... It's dated Friday.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: The day before his last phone call to me.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: He's worked at White and Blazevich in the oil and gas section for five years. During that time, he worked for a client who was engaged in a huge lawsuit in south Louisiana. The client was a man named Victor Mattiece. Darby looks at Gray. She doesn't know whether to laugh or cry.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Keep going.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (scanning the document) Whom he'd never met... Lots about the lawsuit and how much it meant to Mattiece. How desperate he was to win it.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: It's as if you wrote it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dino's : A partner named F, Sims Wakefield supervised the case for W. & B. Morgan worked on the periphery of the case. BRAKES SQUEAL LOUDLY, and they brace for the impact. A car barely misses them.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Keep reading. Gray yanks the gearshift into drive, and pulls the right front wheel over the curb and onto the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: He took a bunch of files and documents that Wakefield left on his desk for him. Not related to the case. When he got back to his own office, he found a handwritten memo on the bottom of the stack of documents. He had inadvertently taken it from Wakefield's desk. A copy of the memo is attached to the affidavit. (examining the documents ) He made a copy of the memo...

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: of Gray and Darby walking into the building.

dialogues.speaker: , DARBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And placed the original in the same position under the files on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM WINDOW IN MADISON HOTEL ACROSS STREET
dialogues.text: Sneller observing them through binoculars. He puts them down and goes to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CLOSE SHOT
dialogues.text: that was in the envelope, now PLAYING on a VCR. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CURTIS MOfcai: (V.0.-) I would swear I'd never seen it. The memo was from M. Velmano, a senior partner. It was dated September 28, directed to Wakefield, and read: CAMERA PANS OVER TO TV screen next to the VCR. It FILLS the THEATER SCREEN. We see Morgan talking.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS MORGAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (reading from the memo ) Sims: Advise client, research is complete and the bench will sit much softer if the old man is retired. The second retirement is a bit unusual. Jensen, of all people. Advise further that the pelican should arrive here in four years, assuming other factors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray and Darby are watching the tape, surrounded by the top editors of the paper. :

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS MORGAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There was no signature. GRANTHAM AND EDITORS’ POV OF TV MONITOR - DAY

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS MORGAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: After I copied it, I folded my copy of the memo and placed it in a desk drawer. Ten minutes later, Wakefield stormed into my office, very disturhed and pale. He scratched around ay desk, and found the memo. He asked if I had read it. No, I insisted. ‘Evidently, I mistakenly picked it up when I left your office,' I explained. "I had no idea until you just reached for it that it was there.’ (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS MORGAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (beat) Then Justices Rosenberg and Jensen were killed. There is no doubt in my mind it was the work of Mattiece and his associates. The memo does not mention Mattiece, but it refers to a ‘client.’ Wakefield had no other clients. And no one client had as much to gain from a new court as Mattiece. I don't know who will see this tape. I'll be dead, so it won’t really matter, I guess. But if the sleazy lawyers are watching this tape, then you can all go straight to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray, Darby and the editors. The tape is over. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH KEEN
dialogues.text: (to Darby) How does it feel to bat a thousand?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Darby looks at Smith. A good man, a bright man, a shrewd man, who has absolutely no ides of what she's ‘eeling. int. HOOVER BUILDING (WASHINGTON) - DIRECTOR'S OFFICE - DA’ Voyles is on the phone. At the same time, he is going over papers.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Voyles, this is Gray Grantham of The Washington Post. We're running a story in the morning detailing a conspiracy in the assinations of Rosenberg and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Voyles looks up from his papers.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We're naming Victor Mattiece, an oil speculator, and two of his lawyers here in town. We believe the F.B.I. knew about Mattiece early on, but refused to investigate at the urging of the White House. We wanted to give you guys a chance to comment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coal is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Are you familiar with the Pelican Brief?

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: (slowly into phone) I am.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We're running a story which, in summary, verifies the facts set forth in that Brief. And we have confirmed that Mr. Mattiece contributed in excess of four Giillion dollars to the President's campaign three years ago.

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: ‘ Four million, two hundred thousand, all through legal channeis.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We also believe the White House intervened and attempted to obstruct the F.B.I. investigation into Mr. Mattiece, and we wanted your comment, if any.

dialogues.speaker: COAL
dialogues.text: The White House emphatically denies any direct or indirect involvement in any aspect of this investigation. You have received some bad information. Sound of ELEVATOR DOOR OPENING over a stunned Coal.

dialogues.speaker: ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: Voyles with K.0. Lewis and two agents in tow. They exit the elevator. :

dialogues.speaker: DARBY AND GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Gray is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: White and Blazevich.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Marty Velmano's office, please.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Velmano's office.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: This is Gray Grantham with the Washington Post, and I need to speak to him. It's very urgent.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: One moment, please. The noisy, busy newsroom suddenly goes silent. Darby and Gray look up. DARBY AND GRANTHAM'’S POV - WIDE ANGLE - NEWSROOM - EVENI Voyles and his entourage, in a historic moment, cross the newsroom to Smith Keen's office. People stop what they're doing to gape. It is as if Voyles and his entourage are walking through a still photograph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith and the editors with Voyles and his entourage.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH KEEN
dialogues.text: (handing Voyles a copy of the draft) Why don't you and Mr. Lewis read a draft of the story. Mr. Grantham, wants you to have the opportunity to comment.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY AND GRANTHA
dialogues.text: Gray is still holding the phone. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: VELMANO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This is Marty Velmano. What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: We're running a story in the morning about your client, Victor Mattiece, and his involvement in the assassinations of Justices Rosenberg and Jensen. He holds the phone so Darby can hear.

dialogues.speaker: VELMANO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Great! We'll sue your ass for the next twenty years! You'll be named as a defendant. This will be great! Victor Mattiece will own the Washington Poat! This is fabulous!

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: I don't know if you've heard of the Pelican Brief. We have a copy. We also have a copy of a memo you sent to Sims Wakefield, dated September 28, in which you suggest your client’ s position will be greatly improved if Rosenberg and Jensen are removed from the court.

dialogues.speaker: VELMANO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I notice you've waited until five o'clock. An hour earlier, and we _ could've run to court and stopped this damned thing.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Do you deny you wrote the memo? VELMANO (¥.0.) It's a frabrication. .

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: There's no lawsuit, Mr. Velmano, and I think you know it.

dialogues.speaker: VELMANO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You son of a bitch. The PHONES CLICK. They are listening to a DIAL TONE. Smith Keen walks over to Gray's desk. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SMITH KEEN.
dialogues.text: I'd like the two of you in the office with Voyles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith, Gray and Darby enter.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH KEEN
dialogues.text: This is Darby Shaw.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: So you're the little lady who started this great brouhaha.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: You're confusing me with a friend of the President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have.some comments for the record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His assistant enters. Coal motions him to shut the door.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: First, we received a copy of the Pelican Brief two weeks ago, and submitted it to the White House on the same day. Coal goes over to the assistant. Both their BACKS ARE TO THE CAMERA when Coal speaks. We do not hear what they're saying.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But it was not considered high priority in the investigation until Mr. Gavin Verheek, Special Counsel to The Director, was found murdered in New Orleans. The CAMERA COMES AROUND TO Coal's and the assistant's faces. It is as if the assistant has been whiplashed.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: At that time, the F.B.I1. immediately began a full-scale investigation of Victor Mattiece. The assistant leaves the office, followed by Coal.  131.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says something to his secretary and exits.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: At this time we are attempting to locate him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coal walks quickly through it. In the b.g., we see the assistant walking just as purposefully in the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Did the White House interfere with your investigation of Mattiece?

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: I'll discuss it off the record. Agreed?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Agreed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President is in the midst of a staged photo op with a foreign dignitary.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ‘Last Wednesday, the President asked me to ignore Victor Mattiece as a suspect. The President and the foreign dignitary beam at each other as flash bulbs go off and TV cameras roll.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: In his words, he asked me to back off.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: I have a tape, which I will not allow anyone to hear unless the President first denies this. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SMITH KEEN
dialogues.text: What do you do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coal, standing behind the reporters and photographers. His face reveals nothing as he waits for the President to finish.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There'll be a grand jury by noon tomorrow. Quick indictment. COAL’S POV - PRESIDENT as he rises, shakes the foreign dignitary's hand and his press spokesman dismisses the reporters.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We'll try to find Mattiece.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Coal comes up to the President. The President introduces him to the foreign dignitary. Coal shakes his hand and beams appropriately. He whispers something to the President, whe nods, but otherwise shows no change in mood. Coal exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are looking THROUGH a window INTO the lighted office. Coal is pacing up and down. The President comes in and shuts the door. He goes over to Coal. We see, but can not hear, as Coal tells the President the terrible news.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: I'd like to spend a few minutes alone with Ma. Shaw. That is, if she doesn't mind.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I'd like Mr. Grantham to stay. The editors and Voyles’ entourage leave. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: What's next for you?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Who killed the man who masqueraded as Gavin Verheek?

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: You mean the assassin, Khamel. Off the record, the man who killed Khamel is a contract operative hired independently by the C.I.A.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (quietly) Rupert.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: He's probably got twenty names.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: Why was he following her?

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: L think the Brief initially scared Gminski more than the rest of us. He probably sent Rupert to trail Darby, in part to watch, and in part to protect.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: She was followed to New York, and she's convinced they're here.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: ’ They're out there. And they're not ail C.I.A.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: We can help. What do you want? DARBY =. I want to leave the country, but when I do, I want to make damned sure no one follows. Mot you, not them, not Rupert nor any of his pals. :

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: Alright. We'll get you out of the building, we'll put you on wy piane and fly you anywhere you want. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can disappear from there. You have my word we will not follow. But you must allow me to contact you through Mr. Grantham here if, and only if, it becomes urgently necessary.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Let's do it like this. I get on the plane, and it's headed for Denver. And no one is on it but me, Gray, and the pilots. And thirty minutes after we take off, I instruct the pilot to go to, let's say, Chicago. Can he do that?

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: He has to file a flight plan before he leaves.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: You're the director of the F.B.I., and you can pull some strings.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: What happens when you get to Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I get off the plane alone, and it returns to Andrews with Gray.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: And what do you do in Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: I get lost in a busy airport, and catch the first flight out.

dialogues.speaker: VOYLES
dialogues.text: When do you wish to leave? She looks at Gray.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: (to Voyles) I'm ready now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen from a HIGH VANTAGE POINT ACROSS the street. Darby and Gray emerge from the building, surrounded by s: armed FBI men using their bodies as shields.  . 135.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sneller, at the window; reaches for-his binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby and Gray, surrounded by the six FBI men. The binoculars SWING OVER TO other FBI men, guns at the ready keeping their eyes on all the tall buildings facing the Washington Post and its parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lone man crouches at the ledge, his rifle next to him. He picks up binoculars and looks through them. ASSASSIN’S POV THROUGH GUNSIGHT - NIGHT Darby and Gray walking towards the parking lot, surrounde by the FBI men. . The IMAGE SWINGS BACK TO the Washington Post and UP, as the assassin SWINGS his binoculars AWAY before putting them down. The binoculars PASS THROUGH them so fast that we barely see the images of men on the roof of the Washington Post

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The assassin reaches for the high-powered rifle next to him, but stops before completing the motion. He reaches for his binoculars again and looks through them, aiming at the roof of the Washington Post.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the roof of the Washington Post, looking back at him with a high-powered infra red camera, taking his picture with a long focus lens -- is one FBI man. Next to him is another with his gun pointed at his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darby and Gray get into the van with the six FBI men. The van moves out into traffic and away.  136.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Voyles watches as Darby anc Grey are escortcd to the FBI plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the FBI plane lands. A special van comes up to it. The door opens. Darby steps out. Gray appears in back of her. He starts to follow her down the steps, but she stops him

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: watching her.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Darby gets into a van. The van drives off towards the terninal.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: devastated at seeing her go.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: He gets back into the plane. The door shuts behind hin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA CLOSELY FOLLOWS Darby in the crowd, then RISES HIG ABOVE, as she is lost in the sea of people hurrying to their destinations. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Voyles' limo drives up. Voyles and two agents jump from the resr of the car and walk to the front door. Voyles holds a newspaper. He bangs the door with his fist. The door opens. Coal stands there in pajamas and a robe. Voyles hands him the newspaper.  137.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON POST
dialogues.text: A picture of the President hugging Mattiece underneath an enormous headline: “SUPREME COURT ASSASSINATION PLOT REVEALED. POSSIBLE OBSTRUCTION OF JUSTICE.”

dialogues.speaker: FOUR TELEVISION MONITORS
dialogues.text: The screen is divided into four boxes, the screens of FOUR TELEVISION MONITORS. They contain images from the morning news shows, jumping from the White House to the Supreme Court, from White & Blazevich, to the Hoover Building. The sound jumps from one to the other and back again as an unseen person switches back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President and Coal watch the debacle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unlike the sea that delivered Khamel, this one is warm an sunny, sensusl, inviting. CAMERA does a ONE HUNDRED-EIGHT DEGREE PAN, REVEALING a pristine beach, a tiny cottage above, and finally Darby, laying on the sands, eyes closed. From the richness of her tan, she could almost be a native. A dark shadow moves over her. She opens her eyes in fear.

dialogues.speaker: GRANTHAM
dialogues.text: still in the clothes he must have traveled in.

dialogues.speaker: DARBY
dialogues.text: Her fear turns into happiness. Her arms reach up to him. FADE OUT.
